delayed edit: I'm well versed in OOP in Delphi and "*came*" to Free Code Camp by accident

Hi everyone! I'm well versed in OOP in Delphi and to Free Code Camp by accident (but a good accident because I thought it'll be nice to contribute to a non-profit and learn another language). I'm going to do that in other languages. However I need to update some C++ device driver code from 32 bit to 64 bit, something completely separate from my original thought for coming to Free Code Camp, so I'm joining here to be in the company of others learning and may be someone advanced who could guide during tough spots :worried:  Thank you!

@notamusician you want one game update loop that reads the state of everything and does the draw call, and then you can use independant std::thread to offload some of your other work to background processes etc

Now, It's up to you : Do you want to prototype a game very fast ? Use tools (unity3D ... again), Do you want to make a first experience in game programming ? Use engines (first, small but yet effective ones like libgdx, then bigger, like ogre or irrlitch, then much bigger commercial solution like cryengine and so on). Do you want to comprehend how all this stuff work together ? Not only focus on a language but on practices, architectures, challenges to face and trade-off to make. Read and read more to only scratch the surface or toying around, participate to coding jam (one game a month or -mini- ludum dare).

There's so much to think about when you code a game that you can't afford "loosing" time by reinventing the wheel (said the man who advised libgdx as a starting point). But reinventing the wheel is also a great way to learn and be aware of some of the issues you've got the face at low level.

Well, if you're new in programming with only a week of practice, you should reconsider build up your first game from C++ libraries and/or engines. Just my two cents. However, making a first experience as a game developer could be done in another language (for convenience, let say Java) with some libraries, say, libgdx + ashley + box2D (in that order).

8 % 10  = 8
